awd_titl_txt: CCF: EAGER:  DeepGreen: Modeling and Boosting Accelerated Computing on Liquid Immersion Cooled HPC Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Power and thermal issues have become critical design constraints that limit performance, scalability, and affordability for high performance computing systems and datacenters. It is urgent to address this challenge as servers are increasingly dense and employing accelerators. Liquid immersion cooling is a potential solution, due to its significantly better thermal conduction and lower power demand than traditional air cooling. This project explores immersion cooling to boost energy efficiency, computing capacity, and reliability of dense servers with multicore and manycore processors and accelerators. It engages both graduate and undergraduate students in research, and inspires and fosters the next generation workforce in technology & engineering. This project promotes green computing, which seeks to reduce energy cost of servers and datacenters. The project features close collaboration with a liquid immersion cooling vendor and will help technology innovation and transfer. 

This project targets dense servers comprising accelerators such as graphics processing units (GPUs), tensor processing units (TPUs), field programmable gate arrays (FPGAs), and application-specific integrated circuits (ASICs). It explores advanced machine learning to automatically learn from multi-physics, diverse data the impact of immersion cooling on performance, power, and thermal, and design model-assisted management schemes to meet various optimization objectives including energy efficiency, performance, and hotspot elimination. Completion of this project will advance the state-of-the-art accelerated computing and datacenter cooling in multiple aspects, including quantitative and comprehensive understanding of the benefits of immersion cooling, more accurate performance, power, and thermal modeling for accelerated systems, and intelligent management software.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we adopt an experimental approach to evaluate the effectiveness of immersion cooling, focusing on its impact on AI and HPC workload execution, as well as hardware temperatures and hotspots. Traditional air cooling is increasingly insufficient and inefficient for supporting the high-density compute environments required by artificial intelligence (AI), machine learning (ML), and high-performance computing (HPC). Liquid immersion cooling, which is significantly more effective than traditional air cooling, is gaining traction in HPC systems and data centers. However, there is a lack of in-depth, real-world case studies exploring how immersion cooling can address critical challenges in energy efficiency and reliability—particularly with GPU accelerators. Developing this understanding is essential for achieving scalable, cost-effective performance growth in HPC applications and systems.

Our experimental case study is centered on the following primary research objectives:

  • Establish the experimental environment, which includes a liquid immersion pod with heat exchange to chilled water and a computer cluster consisting of CPUs and GPUs housed within the pod.
  • Design toolkits for thermal, performance, and power measurement and data collection.
  • Analyze the thermal behavior of individual hardware components, such as CPUs, GPUs, and memory, within the pod.
  • Investigate the impact of initial coolant temperatures on heat dissipation.
  • Identify correlations between workload characteristics and the associated cooling demands.

Our main outcomes encompass multiple perspectives, as outlined below. 

 Research findings. Key findings include:

  • Workload Impact on Thermal Pressure: Compute-intensive workloads place the highest thermal pressure on computing devices.
  • Thermal Behavior of Devices: GPU devices, particularly GPU cores, experience the fastest temperature rise compared to CPUs.
  • Effectiveness of Liquid Immersion Cooling: Liquid immersion cooling effectively evens out hot spots by circulating coolant and lowering temperatures through heat exchange with chilled water.

Additionally, our research highlighted several challenges that hinder the widespread adoption of immersion cooling:

  • Hardware Compatibility: The need for liquid cooling-ready computers and devices, as retrofitting air-cooled systems poses a high risk of hardware damage.
  • Setup Complexity: The complexity of connecting to chilled water systems and the limited space available for connecting devices in the pod.
  • Labor Intensity: The significant manpower required to place and remove computers from the cooling pods.
  • Delayed Cooling Response: The lack of integrating the computers’ sensors into the activation of heat exchange.

Publications. This project has resulted in several notable publications. Among these, two are particularly for liquid immersion cooling and sustainable supercomputing:

  • One paper, titled Thermal Behaviors in Liquid Immersion Cooling under Various Workloads: A Case Study, is the first of its kind to study the thermal behaviors of liquid immersion cooling for high-performance computing and machine learning workloads. This paper was published at the 15th International Green and Sustainable Computing Conference (IGSC).
  • Another paper, titled Vendor-neutral and Production-grade Job Power Management in High-Performance Computing, presents a job-level power management framework based on Flux, utilized on the Lassen (IBM Power AC922) and Tioga (HPE Cray EX235A) systems at the Lawrence Livermore National Lab. This paper was published at the Sustainable Supercomputing Workshop, held in conjunction with Supercomputing 2024.

 Ph.D. Dissertation. This project encompasses research questions that contribute to a Ph.D. dissertation: Thomas Randal, A Systemic Approach to Maximize Heterogeneous System Performance (Expected May 2025).

Student Training. Four graduate students and one undergraduate student participated in the research activities. These activities provided valuable experience and nurtured an interest in liquid immersion cooling and thermal management for high-performance computing. Several students achieved notable milestones, including Thomas Randall, who is pursuing a research position at a DOE lab following his PhD studies.

Curriculum Integration. The research findings from this grant have been integrated as course modules into the graduate course CPSC8200: Parallel Architectures, which is regularly taught by the instructor.

Broader impact. The PI actively works to attract underrepresented students to the research projects supported by this grant. Wayne Ellerbe is a minority REU participant and a first-generation college student. He focused on developing the roofline model for deep learning models and frameworks across various GPU architectures.

Public Access. The source code for power management in Flux has been integrated. Additionally, all related publications have been released for public access.

In summary, PI Ge has successfully conducted experimental studies on liquid immersion cooling, uncovering detailed insights into the thermal behaviors of HPC and ML workloads, as well as the challenges of implementing a liquid immersion cooling environment. This project has provided valuable opportunities for both graduate and undergraduate students to engage in research and gain practical, hands-on experience. The methodologies and findings have been integrated into graduate-level courses, enriching a diverse student community. Additionally, all published papers have been made publicly accessible online, contributing to national and international research and education efforts in energy-efficient computing.
